Review on micro/nano phase change materials for solar thermal applications
Lin Qiu a, b, Yuxin Ouyang a, b, Yanhui Feng a, b, *, Xinxin Zhang a, b
a School of Energy and Environmental Engineering, University of Science and Technology Beijing, Beijing, 100083, China b Beijing Key Laboratory of Energy Saving and Emission Reduction for Metallurgical Industry, University of Science and Technology Beijing, Beijing, 100083, China

Keywords: Micro/nano phase change material Thermal enhancement Thermal energy storage Solar thermal application
* Corresponding author. School of Energy and Env versity of Science and Technology Beijing, Beijing, 100
E-mail address: yhfeng@me.ustb.edu.cn (Y. Feng).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.renene.2019.03.088 0960-1481/© 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
Solar energy, which is welleknown for its inexhaustible and environmentally friendly properties, is among the most promising sources of energy. Solar energy is usually collected by a heat mediumeheat transfer fluid (HTF) in the form of heat and is then transported to production and human use. Due to the challenges of variant weather, climate and seasons, solar heating or power supply devices based on thermal energy storage (TES) components that can operate continuously and without interruption are needed. Phase change materials (PCMs) as latent heat storage material have considerably smaller weights and volumes to store larger amount of energy, which can help the solar thermal equipment capture more solar energy. Nevertheless, conventional PCMs with low thermal conductivity (TC) lead to long energy storage/release times for TES components, which significantly reduces the TES efficiency. To improve the overall TES performance, the key is to accelerate the heat storage/release process via boosting the TC of the PCMs. Based on cuttingeedge theoretical and experimental studies, we review the typical thermal enhancement advances in micro/nanoePCMs in this field.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Since the beginning of human history, the energy consumption capacity has been chosen as a key index to reflect the development level of human society, among which fossil energy has been the backbone of the energy industry since the 19th century. As the pollution of the natural environment and the shortage of fossil energy have considerable impacts on daily life, it is important to efficiently harness new energy sources [1e3]. Solar energy has begun to attract considerable attention owing to its inexhaustible and environmentally friendly properties; thus, it is regarded as an ideal new energy source. However, due to the challenges of variant weather, climates and seasons, the uninterrupted operation of solar heating or power supply devices has become a research hotspot. Thermal energy storage (TES) is a significant component for renewable energy reuse, such as solar energy. Depending on two main storage technologies, i.e., sensible heat storage and latent heat storage, TES allows excess thermal energy to be stored and used at a
ironmental Engineering, Uni083, China.
later time. According to the technology roadmap on energy storage published by the International Energy Agency in 2014, as the core components for latent heat storage, the main mission of micro/ nanoephase change materials (micro/nanoePCMs) for solar thermal applications is to alleviate part of the intermittency problem of solar energy and increase the daily TES efficiency of solar thermal applications, such as solar power plants. Additionally, the solar thermal applications using micro/nanoePCMs also lead to improved economics and less pollution to the environment. In short, the use of micro/nanoePCMs is believed to be a reliable method to produce an uninterrupted power supply and sustainable ecological development [4e8].
PCMs store and utilize energy via heat absorption/release with the outside when physical state conversion occurs between the solideliquid phases. PCMs can replace conventional heat storage materials owing to their excellent TES capacity and controllability. To avoid leakage of PCMs into the surroundings during the phase change process, it is necessary to encapsulate PCMs. Generally, there are three scales of encapsulated PCMs, i.e., macroscale (above 1mm), microscale (~mm) and nanoscale (below 1000 nm). The TES capacity of macroscale PCMs failed to meet the needs of the energy industry due to their weak thermal stability and relatively low thermal conductivity (TC). To overcome this challenge, novel PCMs
containing micro/nanoescale components with excellent thermal stability and heat storage/release rates have been emerging. The microeencapsulated PCMs (microePCMs) have the following advantages compared to macroscale PCMs: (1) excellent thermal transport capability because of the larger heat exchange area; (2) lower reactivity of the PCMs with the outside environment; and (3) easier volume controllability of the PCMs when the phase change occurs. The nanoeencapsulated PCMs (nanoePCMs) are further reduced in size by inheriting the advantages of microePCMs, which brings about a better thermal transport capability. In addition, smalleresized nanoePCMs work better when used as colloidal suspensions for TES, since nanoePCMs are less prone to clog by reducing the viscosity of the fluid during the flowing [9e11]. Since 2008, PCMs have begun to be encapsulated into micro/nano structured shells, andmass ratios up to 300wt% have been found to possess excellent TES performance [12]. Numerous researchers have conducted microencapsulation experiments to explore the most suitable micro/nanoePCMs. It has been reported that the materials for the shell and PCM preparations and the microencapsulation approaches exhibit remarkably different reinforcement effects on the TES capacity [13]. A good example comes from the microencapsulation experiments with cellulose/graphene nanoplatelet (GNP) aerogel and polyethylene glycol (PEG) [14], which were confirmed to achieve satisfactory TC (1.35W/mK, 463% higher than without GNP) and latent heat (LH) of fusion (156.1 J/g) [15]. Micro/nanoePCMs have become the fundamental elements in the phase change energy storage fields. Micro/nanoePCMs are becoming important components in solar energy recycling. These components include solar water heaters (SWH), solar air heaters (SAH), solar thermal power exchangers and solar coolers, which will be discussed in detail in the review.
It is to be noted that PCMs generally possess low TC. This poor thermal transport property clearly hinders the heat storage/release process and thus leads to the low efficiency of the TES systems. Thermal transport enhancement, or simply thermal enhancement, of the shell or matrix of PCMs, is widely believed to be an effective means of attaining high efficiency TES. In this study, the stateeofethe art thermal enhancement approaches of PCMs will be reviewed to illustrate their ability to boost the energy storage capacity.

sections.heading: 2. Application of recently developed PCMs in solar TES devices
sections.text:
TES devices are extremely important for the uninterrupted use of solar energy. PCMs have better TES capacity than sensible heat storage materials due to their great LH. Hence, using PCMs as heat storagematerials is a vital part of solar heat storage/release devices; For most solar thermal applications (e.g., solar water heaters, solar air heaters and solar power plants), using a heat transfer fluid (HTF) as a heat medium is necessary to sustain the heat exchange (the thermal energy transfers from the sunlight to the fluid). After the PCMs are loaded, the energy transfer mode has changed. Thermal energy from the sunlight not only transfers to the HTF but also to the PCMs receiving thermal energy from both the sunlight and the fluid. At night, thermal energy transfers from the PCMs to the fluid to ensure more solar energy can be used. Therefore, PCMs are used to store the excess heat previously stored in the fluid, which is different from mass storage including the mass transfer process. Since different types of PCMs have different characteristics and application ranges, it is important to choose the most suitable type of PCMs for the specific application. In this section, we will review the typical categories of PCMs and their characteristics. Representative solar TES devices using PCMs as the main energy storage component will be presented in detail.
2.1. Categories of micro/nanoePCMs
As shown in Fig. 1, the typical categories of micro/nanoePCMs for solar thermal applications include organic, inorganic and composite (organiceorganic, inorganiceinorganic and organiceinorganic). The most common PCMs are organic, but inorganic PCMs are also used in some fields because of the low volume change and cost. Given the intrinsic shortcomings of organic and inorganic PCMs, composites of organiceorganic, inorganiceinorganic and organiceinorganic PCMs are currently the research hotspot. Some representative organic, inorganic and composite PCMs will be introduced in following subesections.

sections.heading: 2.1.1. Organic
sections.text:
Organic PCMs generally include paraffin and noneparaffin
PCMs for solar thermal applications.
categories. Noneparaffin PCMs are mostly fatty acids and PEG. Organic PCMs have the following advantages: (1) a large phase change temperature range, (2) a high LH of fusion, (3) no need for supercooling, (4) good stability and recyclability, and (5) high compatibility. However, the low TC and unstable volume change hinder the heat storage/release of a single organic PCM [16,17]. Table 1 summarizes the recent progress in organic PCMs. The PCMs' good thermal reliability is confirmed by repeatable melting and solidification cycling experiments (up to 5000 times for neheptadecane capsules and 500 times for PEG600 PCMs by Sari et al. [18,19]). The considerable energy storage is validated by using SiO2 shells [20], CaCO3 shells [21] and ZnO shells [22]. However, it is clearly observed that the PCMs' TC values are still low, e.g., 0.139W/ mK in the work of Fang et al. [20]. Hence, improving the TC of organic PCMs is urgently needed in future work.

sections.heading: 2.1.2. Inorganic
sections.text:
To deal with the low TC and unstable volume change problems of conventional organic PCMs, inorganic PCMs have been invented with the benefits of low cost and high LH of fusion. However, the accompanying disadvantages, such as supercooling and corrosive issues, lead to additional requirements of the equipment and method to ensure the normal operation of the phase change
process and adequate service life of the PCMs [16,23]. Generally, metallic and salt hydrate PCMs are the typical inorganic PCMs. Table 2 summarizes the key thermal parameters for inorganic PCMs from recent studies [24e31].
The high melting point and high TC values [24e27] characteristic of metallic PCMs make them an innovative choice for highetemperature TES applications. Metallic PCMs generally can implement the phase change within a shorter time than salt hydrates. For instance, the Pb capsules (~29W/mK) need 280 s to finish melting, whereas the NaNO3 capsules (0.5W/mK) need 380 s [25]. It should be noted that salt hydrate PCMs have the benefits of high LH, lowecost and nonecombustibility, therefore, they are also leaving a mark in PCM applications [25].

sections.heading: 2.1.3. Composite
sections.text:
In addition to the single type PCMs, the mixture of multiple PCMs also play a key role in TES development. The most common mixing method is eutectics, which mixes two or more components to form a minimumemelting composition with a congruent form [32]. The resultant PCMs possess the benefits of a sharp melting temperature and high volumetric TES density.
As shown in Table 3, Fauzi et al. fabricated myristic acid/palmitic acid (MA/PA) (mass ratioz 7:3) eutectic PCMs and used sodium
laurate (SL) as an acidebased surfactant to improve their LH and TC, but the TC still exhibited a low level [33]. Furthermore, these researchers added 5% sodium myristate (SM) and 5% sodium palmitate (SP) into MA/PA eutectic PCMs. After 0, 1000, 2000, 3000, and 3600 heating/cooling cycling tests, the eutectic PCMs still had better thermal stability and higher LH than the counterparts without SM and SP additives [33,34]. After eutectic mixing of several pure metals, the formed metallic PCMs possessed remarkably improved LH and TC values [25e27,35e37]. Though the LH of salt hydrate eutectic PCMs improved, their TC remained at a low level [27,38,39].
2.2. Applications of micro/nanoePCMs
The development of a higheefficiency TES system is crucial to the future development of solar energy recycling technologies. Usually, the energy is obtained from excess heat or irregular sources (e.g., solar radiation, waste heat) and is then conveyed to TES systems via HTF. There are two typical processes for the TES system. One is the “charge” process, where the TES system recovers the thermal energy of the HTF. The other is the “discharge” process, where the HTF is heated when the solar radiation amount decreases. In this section, the representative applications of micro/ nanoePCMs in solar energy storage are reviewed, including the direct usage of thermal energy (water and air heaters) and the indirect energy conversion (electric energy and cooling capacity).

sections.heading: 2.2.1. Solar water heater
sections.text:
For SWHs, the water flows through a higheTC tube/flat that is
Fig. 2. Thermal performance of an integrated collector storage solar water heating pipe: (a) (b) Variation of the water average temperature during 24 h (beginning at 6 a.m.) (Reprint Thermal performance of an integrated collector storage solar water heater (ICSSWH) with ph
heated by solar energy. Then, thewater is stored in a container with good thermal insulation, which can provide hot water continuously. To cope with the problem that the water becomes cold at night, an intermediate heat storage material to store the solar energy in the daytime is required to heat the water at a low temperature. Therefore, it is better to combine PCM technologies with SWHs. Different from normal SWHs, the addition of PCMs in the TES module of the SWH collect the excess heat from both the water and sunlight, which ensures more solar energy can be conveyed to the water due to the extended working hours, further increasing the efficiency of the SWH. The recent work on SWHs has also demonstrated this to be an effective approach for solar thermal applications.
For the common SWH, the water flowing in pipes (usually made of copper) is heated and is collected by the solar thermal energy. Chaabane et al. used myristic acid or RT42egraphite PCMs, which were incorporated into the pipes [40]. As shown in Fig. 2a, the numerical simulation results based on fluid dynamics show that the total temperature of the heater with PCMs was considerably higher than that without PCMs at 6 p.m., and the insulation capacity was also more powerful than that without PCMs (Fig. 2b).
For SWHs, such as heat exchangers, PCMs are used as the heat accumulator, exchanging thermal energy with water; that is, the hot water is heated by the sun and then flows to heat the PCMs, while the flowing cold water is heated by the PCMs. Chaichan et al. invented a water solar distiller for this system [41]. As shown in Fig. 3a, the distiller system includes the following three main parts: (1) a solar energy receiver, (2) a heat exchanger based on paraffin wax, and (3) a distiller. In the day time, the receiver collects the
Crossesectional schematic of the integrated collector storage solar water heating pipe, ed from Energy Conversion and Management, 78, M. Chaabane, H. Mhiri, P. Bournot, ase change materials (PCM), 897e903, Copyright(2018), with permission from Elsevier).
solar energy and heats the water, and the water flows into the distiller after heating the PCMs. At night, the PCMs heat the water by releasing the LH. To collect more solar energy, sun tracking is also installed on the receiver. After the tests, the concentrating efficiency, heating efficiency and productivity for the water solar distiller with both PCMs and sun tracking increased by 64.07%, 112.87% and 307.54%, respectively (Fig. 3bed).
AleKayiem et al. improved the SWH system by enhancing the thermal transport between the pipe and PCMs (paraffinwax) using fins and Cu nanoparticles without affecting the solar energy collection (Fig. 4). According to these researchers' results, the TC of the CuePCM nanocomposite was boosted by 24% compared to the pure paraffin wax, and the TES efficiency increased by 8.4% more than the case without PCMs and by 1.5% more than that with pure paraffin wax [42]. This limited enhancement is reasonable, as the experiment conducted in Malaysia, where the night temperature is higher than that at the mainland, and AleKayiem et al. thought the flow rate could affect the TES. The relation between the flow rate and TES was developed byMahfuz et al. [43] later. It was found that when the flow rate of the water increased from 0.033 kg/min to 0.167 kg/min, the energy efficiency increased from 63.88% to 77.41%. Moreover, the exergy efficiency decreased from 9.58% to 6.02%, while the total life cycle cost (sum of the lost energy cost, lost exergy cost and material cost) decreased from $ 654.61 to $ 609.22.
Based on the abovementioned work and some others [44,45], the TES of SWHs needs further improvement in several areas, as follows: (1) improved PCMs with great thermal stability, (2) improved system design, such as PCM usage to reduce the energy loss of water conveying pipeline, and (3) reasonable practical applications, such as the standardization and improved economic value of the water heater equipment.

sections.heading: 2.2.2. Solar air heater
sections.text:
Similar to the mechanism of the SWH, the SAH uses collected solar energy to heat the air. The representative types of SAHs include the SAH with a noneporous absorber plate (flat, veeecorrugated, fins) and the SAH with a porous absorber plate (packed bed, overlapped glass, matrix) [46]. The PCMs play a similar function in the solar energy recycling of SAHs, i.e., collecting thermal energy from sun and heating air in the daytime and then using this energy to keep heating the air when the sun goes down. Recently, it has been confirmed that the daily air heating energy efficiency increases after the usage of PCMs. Khadraoui et al. filled the conventional air heater with paraffin wax to enhance the daily energy efficiency [47]. As shown in Fig. 5, the fan drains the air to the heating channel and the sun heats both the air and the PCMs. When the surrounding temperature drops to the phase change point of the PCMs, the air is heated by the LH released from the PCMs. It is found that the highest temperatures of the outlet air and the absorber with PCMs are lower than the case without PCMs, but the temperature at night increases after PCMs are used. The daily energy efficiency with PCMs can reach 33% compared with 17% without PCMs.
Kabeel et al. further studied the effect of different SAH plate types (flat, Veeecorrugated, fins) [48,49]. Similar to the results by Khadraoui et al., the bottom of the collector box was filled with paraffin wax PCMs, and the thermal energy was exchanged among the PCMs, the absorber plate and the air (Fig. 6a). The operating period was extended after the addition of the PCMs (Fig. 6c,e), and the Veeecorrugated plate and finned plate had better effects on TES than the flat plate. The daily energy efficiencies for the PCMsecontaining SAHs were improved by 6.3%, 12%, 13.6%. The PCMs solidification time was shortened by the introduction of a
noneflat plate [49]. Therefore, it is concluded that the PCMsecontaining SAH has excellent TES capability and a remarkably prolonged heating time. Although the main function of a SAH is still air drying, it can also be used for energy saving. For example, Stritih et al. developed a SAH for reducing the heat loss of ventilation air [50], and the cost in the heating season was successfully decreased by 24% after the SAH was used.

sections.heading: 2.2.3. Solar thermal power exchanger
sections.text:
A solar thermal power exchanger is a system that uses solar thermal energy to heat up HTF. In brief, the water of the HTF evaporates into steam, which drives the power generation bloc (Rankine cycle, Stirling cycle et al.) to produce electricity. Since various forms of energy conversion processes involve in the solar thermal power exchanger, the heating form and thermal circulation system are more complicated than those of the SWH and SAH. The
large amount of cyclic energy demand also necessitates efficient photothermal energy conversion of the solar energy collector. Throughout the solar power plants in the world, the concentrated solar power (CSP) technologies are most successful for high density solar energy conversion. The currently developed CSP technologies include parabolic trough collectors (PTC), linear Fresnel reflectors (LFR), solar power towers (SPT) and parabolic dish collectors (PDC), of which the PTC is the most developed and used in solar power plants. However, the solar temporal intermittency restricts the further improvement of energy efficiency. The peak period of electricity consumption is not consistent with that of solar radiation (Fig. 7a) [51]. Therefore, the CSP plant with the TES system has been very popular in recent years (Fig. 7b and c) [52]. We will illustrate several representative cases in the following section.
Exergy analysis is one of the important tools for assessing the thermodynamic properties of solar energy plants. Based on a CSP plant with a TES system, Mahfuz et al. used PCMs with a melting temperature below 265 C as the TES materials [53]. According to their results, the energy efficiency of the CSP system (where they use a PTC system) without the TES component was approximately 30%, and the exergetic efficiency was below 10%. After using PCMs as the TES materials, the exergetic efficiency increased up to 30%. In addition to using HTF for the steam production, direct watereheating by solar energy is also a feasible method. A system designed by Bay on et al. used KNO3/NaNO3 eutectic mixture PCMs to store/release the thermal energy of steam, which fulfilled the power generation [54]. The period of either the “charge” or “discharge” process was only 45min, which ensured a fast heat exchange process. The thermal power of this systemwas estimated to be 50 kW, which matched the true situation well when the TC of the PCMs was 8W/mK.
To further enhance the thermal transport, it is necessary to design a suitable PCMefins heat exchanger system [55,56]. Generally, the fins are set up in PCMs (outetube) or HTF (inetube). For the outetube fins, Fig. 8a illustrates the initial model with Cu fins. After optimizing the geometry of the shape factor (the ratio of the length to height of fin), the power efficiency was improved by 200% compared to the noneoptimized configuration [55]. For the inetube fins, the heat transfer coefficient of the finned tube (Fig. 8b) was 2200W/m2K, two times that of the bare tube (1100W/ m2K). By using PCMs enhanced with particle suspension, the conversion efficiency grew above the current 40%, and even exceeded 50% in the combined cycle power generation plant [56]. The TES systems in CSP plants include sensible heat energy storage technologies. Since micro/nanoePCMs are emerging in an endless
stream, CPS systems obtain remarkably improved, and LHebased plants are increasingly under production and construction [52].

sections.heading: 2.2.4. Solar cooler
sections.text:
Typically, cooling methods based on solar energy have two forms. One form is that the solar power plant produces electric energy to provide the cooling capacity, and the other is that the thermal energy from solar energy directly provides the cooling capacity by thermoemechanical or sorption means. It is known that the coefficient of performance (COP) is an evaluation indicator for the quality of the cooling capacity in the refrigeration industry. Hence, this step is essential towards boosting the COP, which reduces the heat removal in the cooling system. PCMs can absorb excess thermal energy from the evaporator and generator, which improves the COP. There are some recent advances in COP enhancement by means of PCMs.
Agyenim et al. used erythritol as the PCMs to absorb the excess thermal energy of solar energy to drive a LiBr/H2O absorption cooling system [57]. According to the information presented in the introduction, organic PCMs have the drawback of low TC. To solve this problem, three types of thermal enhancement approaches have been developed in PCMs, i.e., circular finned, longitudinal finned and multietube PCM systems. The experimental result showed that the combination of multietube and longitudinal finned PCMs boosted the overall utilization efficiency to 82.2% in the heat exchange system. A similar conclusion was also drawn by Palomba et al. [58], who pointed out that the thermal energy density increased by approximately 50% after replacing water with organic PCMs in the cooling system, and a further boost could be achieved if the TC was increased.
In addition to the fin installation, the temperature and flow rate of the inlet HTF also have great effects on the cooler performance, including cold storage and exergy efficiency. A study by Cheng et al. showed that the charging rate and charging capacity increased by 73.9% and 44.7% when the temperature of the inlet HTF dropped from 12 C to 7 C, while there was little effect on discharging and exergy efficiency [59]. As the flow rate of the inlet HTF increased from 50 L/h to 250 L/h, the average charging rate and cold storage increased by 25% and 15.2%, while the exergy efficiency declined by 38.7% [59]. According to these results, it is clear that the COP of the PCMsecontaining cooling system will obtain a remarkable boost with the appropriate configuration of the multietube with PCMs and its circular and longitudinal surface fins. Thus, a novel solar cooler led by PCMs will improve our lives in the near future.
Due to the excellent capability of micro/nanoePCMs, there are
infinite possibilities in the higheefficiency exploitation of solar energy. The thermally enhanced PCMs that use high TC nanoparticles or fins are more popular in applications, especially for the organic PCMs. In the next two sections, the effects of some representative enhancement approaches, e.g., the nanoparticles and skeleton, will be discussed in detail.

sections.heading: 3. Approaches for the inclusion of highly thermally conductive particles in PCMs
sections.text:
As mentioned previously, PCMs have huge TES capabilities and wide temperature ranges, while their low TC limits their applications in heat exchange equipment, which requires a high storage/ release speed. Therefore, highly thermally conductive nanoparticles (mostly metal nanopowders) are added into the PCMs to break through the barrier of the low heat storage/release speed of PCMs via boosting their TC (Fig. 9). In this section, the main types of thermal enhancement methods (e.g., solid nanoparticle addition, nanostructureebased colloidal suspension usage) will be reviewed.
reduce the storage/release time for facilitating solar thermal energy exchange.

sections.heading: 3.1. Nanoparticles for thermal enhancement
sections.text:
In the typical thermal enhancement phase, solid nanoparticles (especially organic PCMs) have been verified to be pivotal to the thermal transport of PCMs in many studies. The most representative nanoparticles used for TC enhancement are nanopowders, nanowires and nanotubes. The nanoparticles for the thermal enhancement of PCMs can bemetal, metal oxide and carbonebased materials. Their thermal enhancement effect strongly depends on
the filling ratio, surface and physical properties. A suitable filling ratio helps to construct an internal thermal transport network in the PCMs, which can achieve the goal of fast heat storage/release.

sections.heading: 3.1.1. Metal nanoparticles
sections.text:
High TC metal nanoparticles are the traditional thermal enhancement materials, e.g., Ag, Cu and Al nanoparticles. The
addition of metal nanoparticles into PCMs can not only retain the good thermal stability of PCMs but can also boost the TC of PCMs. For instance, the TC of PEG/Ag nanoparticles (diameter: 3e10 nm) was 0.82W/mK, 127% higher than that of PEG/diatomite [60]. The storage/release time was reduced by 34% and 25% compared with the case of PEG/diatomite. Similar results were reported for the Cu nanoparticles [61] and Ag nanowires [62]. The addition of Cu nanoparticles (diameter: ~25 nm) brought about an 11.32% TC boost and a 30% storage/release time reduction. The enhanced thermal transport speed by nanoparticles will increase the efficiency of the TES in solar thermal applications, as corroborated by the improved SWH from a study by AleKayiem et al. [42]. After Cu nanoparticles were added into the PCMs of SWHs, the efficiency increased 21.7% compared to the case without the addition of nanoparticles.
However, the unavoidable oxidation phenomenon makes it difficult to use active metal nanoparticles, such as Al nanoparticles, in PCMs. To solve this problem, the active metal nanoparticles need to be mixed with another substance before their usage in PCMs. For example, carbon shells with a thickness of 4 nm were used to encapsulate 50e100enmesized Al nanoparticles [63]. The thermally conductive networks braided by these nanoparticles were proven to boost the TC of paraffinwax by 206.5% (Fig. 10). It is to be noted that the preparation of those multielayered nanoparticles is much more complicated. Therefore, the applications of metal oxide nanoparticles are more popular than metal nanoparticles in PCMs.

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Metal oxide nanoparticles
sections.text:
After the chemical reaction between active metals and oxygen, the formed oxides have chemical and thermal stability, and some metal oxides even have high TC. Therefore, the addition of metal oxide nanoparticles in PCMs can also improve the thermal transport speed and TES. In addition, some nonemetal oxide nanoparticles, such as mesoporous silica (MPSiO2) nanoparticles, can boost the TC of PCMs. Table 4 summarizes the recent studies on thermal enhancement by means of metal oxide and nonemetal oxide nanoparticles, in which some PCM composites have considerable potential in TES applications, especially solar energy
[64e68]. The PCMs with oxide nanoparticles not only maintain stability well during the solidification/melting cycles but also achieve higher TC. Inspired by these findings, it is safe to conclude that the good dispersion of nanoparticles is one of the cornerstones for the thermal enhancement of PCMs. For the practical application of nanoparticleeenhanced PCMs, we need to balance between the thermal enhancement effect and the cost of nanoparticles usage.
3.1.3. Carbonebased nanoparticles Although the addition of metal or metal oxide nanoparticles can enhance the TC of PCMs, the price is a significant reduction in the LH. As a representative nonemetal material with high TC, carbon derivative materials, such as multielayer carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs), graphite and graphene, have become popular in many studies [69e71]. The use of carbon derivative materials, such as thermal enhancement components, in PCMs is not inferior to metallic materials. Their thermal and chemical stabilities are even better than that of metallic materials. Therefore, there is no need to add a protective substance into the PCMs to keep the carbon derivative materials (e.g., carbonebased nanoparticles, carbon nanotubes (CNTs)) away from the external environment.
Recent advances show that carbonebased nanoparticles can double the TC of organic PCMs, which brings about a breakthrough where the organic PCMs are able to exceed the threshold of 1W/ mK. These promising organic PCMs with excellent thermal properties [72e76] are listed in Table 5.
Under the synergy of carbonebased nanoparticles, the PCM composites have efficiently improved the performance of solar equipment. Following the work of Sharshir et al. [77], four modifications were designed in a water solar distiller, as follows: (A) the addition of flake graphite nanoparticles, (B) the addition of flake graphite nanoparticles and PCMs, (C) the addition of flake graphite nanoparticles and film cooling, and (D) the addition of flake graphite nanoparticles, PCMs, and film cooling (shown in Fig. 11). It is clear that the combination of PCMs, high TC nanoparticles and the other thermal enhancement parts brings about a greater improvement in the productivity of distilled water for solar thermal applications.
According to the previous reports on nanoparticleebased thermal enhancement, the TC of PCMs is remarkably improved by
constructing thermal transport networks, which are braided by high TC nanoparticles. The constructed composites render slightly lower LH values compared to pure PCMs. However, the thermal transport networks can facilitate the heat flow to go deep into the innermost PCMs and tightly maintain the structure. Hence, the storage/release time of the composite PCMs becomes considerably shorter than with pure PCMs.
3.2. Nanostructureebased colloidal suspension for thermal enhancement
The colloidal suspension is generally prepared by combining pure PCMs and nanostructure materials (e.g., nanoparticles, nanofibres and nanotubes), which exhibits liquidelike properties once the PCMs melt. The colloidal suspension has attracted much attention owing to the high TES, high TC and good flow characteristics. Much of the current research has focused on developing PCM emulsions by finding suitable processing conditions.
3.2.1. Nanoparticleebased colloidal suspensions Similar to the conventional PCMs, adding high TC nanoparticles can improve the thermal performance of the colloidal suspension PCMs. These colloidal nanofluids with phase change behaviour are molten fluids mixed with a colloidal suspension and nanoparticles. A good example is KNO3 molten salt fluids with 2e100 nm oxide nanoparticles, such as Al2O3, SiO2, and hydrophilic fumed mixed SiO2 and Al2O3 nanoparticles [78]. Generally, the melting point of
colloidal suspension PCMs were unchanged after the addition of nanoparticles. However, the LH was remarkably changed. It was reported that the single species of nanoparticles increased the LH of the PCMs, but the hydrophilic fumed mixing nanoparticles reduced the LH of the PCMs. In terms of TESs, the specific heat increased by 5%e9.5% after the addition of nanoparticles, which led to a 16% rise of the TES. In the preparation of the colloidal suspension, the addition of surfactants can effectively reduce the supercooling degree of the colloidal suspension PCMs, and the introduction of nanoparticles can boost the TC, which perfectly solves the twomain problems of colloidal suspension PCMs. For example, the graphite nanoparticles dispersed phase change emulsion (2wt% graphite nanoparticle) exhibited excellent thermal reliability, which was corroborated by the negligible change of the average droplet diameter of the emulsion after tests of more than 300 heatingecooling cycles [79]. The TC of the emulsion enhanced greatly as the mass fraction of the graphite nanoparticle increased, and the enhancement factor reached over 100% when the addition mass fraction was 4wt%.
In addition to the abovementioned methods, another feasible way to prepare nanoparticleebased colloidal suspensions is mixing encapsulated PCMs and encapsulated nanoparticles in the fluid. Hong et al. developed a type of this colloidal suspension [80]. In addition, by using the polymereencapsulated paraffin wax nanoparticles as the phase change component and the silicaeencapsulated indium nanoparticles as the thermal enhancement component, Hong et al. prepared a polyeReolefin (PAO)/water colloidal suspension that can maintain circulation between the heat source and the cold source. Fig. 12 illustrates the preparation process of the colloidal suspension containing encapsulated phaseechange nanoparticles. In brief, the paraffin wax absorbed thermal energy from a heat source into a liquid and released heat energy into a solid in a cold source. The polymer protected it from leaking easily during the cycle. The common solidification/melting model for nano PCMs can be expressed by the following equation:
ðTs TmÞ RM þ RShell ¼ 4prDHslr2 dr dt

where RM¼ [1/(4pkM)]∙[(1/r)e(1/rM)], RShell¼ [1/(4pkShell)]∙[(1/ rM)e(1/rShell)], T is the temperature, DH is the latent heat, k is the thermal conductivity, and t is the melting time when the solid radius is r. The subscript m denotes themelting point, and s denotes the solidification point; sl represents the fusion of the nano PCMs, M represents the nano PCMs and Shell denotes the shell encapsulated nano PCMs. Owing to the high TC of the silica shell (~1.3W/ mK) and indium (~81.8W/mK), there was enough time for this suspension to complete the phase change at the high flow rate (210mL/min). Finally, a high heat transfer coefficient of ~175% was achieved compared to conventional singleephase fluids, which
brought about a fast phase change process in cycles.
3.2.2. Nanotubeebased colloidal suspensions Compared with nanoparticles with uniform shapes, nanomaterials with large aspect ratios can give the composite excellent rigidity. Owing to ultraehigh thermal and electrical conduction, nanotubeebased materials are more likely to form conductive networks under the same amount of addition. The doubleewalled CNTs (DWCNTs) were validated to be well-dispersed into the palmitic acid once their surfaces were modified by hydroxide radical functional groups, which could implement the role of surfactants (usually acid treatment) [81]. As the number of DWCNTs increased, the TC increased to ~146%, which is higher than the effect achieved by acid treatment. This finding was observed because the acid heavily damaged the carbon materials and deteriorated the intrinsic thermal transport. It was also an effective approach to disperse the derivative of the CNTs to achieve high TC colloidal suspensions, such as dispersing singleewalled carbon nanohorns (SWCNHs) into lauric acid [82]. An ~37% TC enhancement occurred in the solid phase and ~10.8% in liquid phase. The melting point and LH also increased due to the large surface area and the increasing molecular density of the SWCNHs.
The addition of nanotubes and nanoparticles into the mixture can further enhance the TC of PCMs. As shown in Fig. 13, the TC of composite PCMs with MWCNT/graphene additives was increased by 115.4%, 31.8%, and 55.4% compared with that of the pure paraffin wax, graphene nanoparticleebased and MWCNTebased composite PCMs, respectively [83]. The underlying mechanism is that the thermal boundary resistance at the interface of the threeedimensional (3D) nanostructure is much higher than that of the twoedimensional (3D) nanostructure when the nanostructures are in contact with each other. MWCNTcan effectively maintain the
2D graphene, which can reduce the thermal boundary resistance. Therefore, the thermal energy storage/release speed of the MWCNT/grapheneebased composite PCM was increased by 63.3% and 50.0% compared to pure paraffin wax.
3.2.3. Nanofibreebased colloidal suspensions Carbon nanofibres (CNFs) are similar to CNTs in growth condition, that is, the carbon feedstock passes over nanosized metal particles at a high temperature to grow into nanofibres or nanotubes. However, CNFs can be visualized along the length of the filament into a regularly stacked truncated conical or planar layer, which is remarkably different from the concentric CNTs with entire hollow cores (Fig. 14(a) and (b)). This unique CNF structure allows them to exhibit semiconductor behaviour and have chemically active end faces on both the inner and outer surfaces [84]. Therefore, the use of CNFs as the thermal enhancement component for
colloidal suspension PCMs is worth exploring. Cui et al. [85] poured the CNFs into the molten soy wax and dispersed them by ultrasonication for the preparation of colloidal suspension PCMs. The TC of the resultant PCMs was increased by 44.8% under a 10wt% addition of CNFs, which is much higher than the effect of CNTs. A similar finding was also obtained by Yu et al. [86], who reported that the TC of the paraffinwaxwas increased by 13.3% after the 4wt % addition of CNFs.
Another important nanoecarbon material is the graphite nanofibre (GNF), which has a carpeterollingesheet structure (Fig. 14(c)). The high strength and modulus along the fibre axis are close to the ideal values of a graphene sheet. According to the current data, some TC calculation models for micro/nanoePCMs with nanoparticles are summarized in Table 6. It is found that the larger the loading of the nanoparticles, the better the thermal exchange performance, reflecting the increasing effective TC. As the herringboneestyle GNFs penetrated into paraffinwax, the TC of the PCM composites increased exponentially in the solid phase, and the TC could increase by 80% under 11.4 vol% herringboneestyle GNFs. However, the TC of the PCMs did not increase significantly in the liquid phase until the volume fraction of the herringboneestyle GNFs exceeded the limit of 8.5 vol%. The TC was increased by 70% if an 11.4 vol% amount of herringboneestyle GNFs was added [87].
Based on the nanoparticleeformed thermal transport networks, the PCM composites can successfully store the external thermal energy into the interior and release it to the outside surroundings. This excellent thermal transport is manifested by such characteristics as the TC, specific heat and thermal energy storage/release rate. In addition, the fluidity of the nanoparticles also enables the colloidal suspension PCMs to quickly complete the phase transition during the flow. Based on the current data, the larger the loading of the nanoparticles, the better the thermal exchange performance. Since the dispersion of nanoparticles is the dominant factor determining the phase change heat of PCM composites, the full dispersion of nanoparticles in PCMs is the key to the development of energy equipment integrated with phase change TES systems.

4. Preparation of PCM composites using foams and fins as the skeleton
In addition to the addition of high TC nanoparticles, the usage of a high TC skeleton is also an important approach to thermally
Fig. 15. Schematic diagrams of PCM com
enhance PCMs. This measurement can also facilitate the fast thermal energy storage/release and insulate the PCMs from the influence of the outside surroundings. The most common skeletons include openecell foam metals and foam graphite. Their complex 3D network structures (Fig. 15(a)), outstanding anisotropic TC and
posites with (a) foams and (b) fins.
large specific surface area endow the composites with ultraehigh TES performance, which is verified by a negligible reduction in the overall TES capacity.
The TES performance is also improved by optimizing the configuration and orientation of the fins. Since the fin efficiency increases as the heat transfer coefficient decreases, it is more suitable to locate the fins on the PCM side with the lower heat transfer coefficient compared to the whole system (Fig. 15(b)). This section will describe the techniques that are currently being studied to enhance our understanding of micro/nanoePCMs.
In short, foam materials accelerate the phase change process by constructing a rapid thermal transport network among the PCMs, while the fins enhance the heat exchange efficiency between the PCMs and the entire TES system. This section will describe the specific techniques developed recently, which will deepen our understanding of micro/nanoePCMs.
4.1. Openecell foam metal/PCMs composites
Openecell foam metal/PCM composites are nonechemical mixtures, in which the melting PCMs (usually organic PCMs) are impregnated into the foam metal. The preparation is sometimes completed with the help of a surfactant. The intimate contact between the foam metal skeleton and the PCMs speeds up the thermal transport; thus, the pore size is one of the important factors that determine the TC of PCM composites. The recent experimental works on the thermal enhancement of openecell foammetal/PCMs are summarized in Table 7. It can be clearly seen that the LH of PCM composites reduced as the pore size or porosity of foam metal decreased [88,89], and the TC exhibited the same dependence on the pore structure of metal foams [88]. In addition to the pore structure, the types of foammaterials also have a large effect on the thermal enhancement. It is obvious from Table 7 that the TC enhancement of Cu is more effective than Ni, while TiO2 foam and carbon composite carbonized in situ by sucrose also improve the TC [89]. The excellent thermal enhancement of foammetal also brings about the superior thermal transport. The ideal cooling effect on Lieion batteries was achieved by paraffin wax and Al foam, with a 26.4% and 25.6% decrease in the phase change time under the simulation of 7000W/m2 and 12,000W/m2 heat fluxes, respectively. This effect brought a 62.5% drop in the maximum temperature rise of the Lieion battery [90].
The thermal enhancement effect of foam metals has also been
demonstrated by the simulation results. A finite element model was developed to study the effects of pore size and porosity of an Al foam/paraffinwax composite. The result exhibited that the thermal transport of the composite was strongly influenced by the pore structure [93]. If the foam pore size decreased to 20 mm, the TC of the composite would increase to 12W/mK, which was more than twice that of the TC with the 100 mm pore size (5W/mK). However, the supercooling phenomenon of the composite became more serious. Therefore, a balance between the TC and the supercooling degree in the pore size choice needs to be reached. The simulation also indicated that the thermal energy charge time of the Cu foam/ paraffin wax composite decreased by 40% compared with that of the pure paraffinwax, which proved the great improvement on the uniformity of the paraffinwax's internal thermal transport by using Cu foam [91]. The photovoltaic thermal system is a hotspot in solar thermal applications. It is composed of multiple solar cells that can directly convert the solar energy to electricity and generate heat simultaneously. Hence, it is necessary to develop a cooling method to ensure the working environment of the photovoltaic thermal system. Owing to the excellent thermal transport brought by Cu foam, the Cu foam/paraffin wax composite can cool the photovoltaic thermal system better via the heat exchange model (Fig. 16).
Moreover, the electrical efficiency of this system is 2.3% higher than the normal photovoltaic thermal system [94].

sections.heading: 4.2. Foam graphite/PCMs composites
sections.text:
Owing to the excellent thermal features of graphite and the
powerful adsorption of foam materials, adding foam graphite into PCMs is regarded as an effectiveway to thermally enhance PCMs. As shown in Fig. 17, after the impregnation of erythritol (approximately 75wt%), the LH of the PCM composites decreased to 251.2 J/ g with a 24% drop, and the TC increased to 3.77W/mK, which was 527% higher than pure erythritol. Moreover, the supercooling
d the elemental mapping of graphite and erythritol in the composite (Reprinted from nno, Preparation of erythritolegraphite foam phase change composite with enhanced ith permission from Elsevier).
degree dropped significantly from 92 C to 55 C because of the graphiteebased nucleation phenomenon, which greatly promoted the usability of composites [95]. In addition to the selfethermal enhancement effect and the lightweight characteristic, the addition of foam graphite can ensure the good TES performance for the graphite/paraffin wax PCM composite [96]. This new composite generally had a 44.95 C melting point, 126.4 J/g LH and 3.13W/mK TC. The composite was then added into the lightweight wall material with a 20 vol%, resulting in a mixture with 23.82 J/g LH and 0.76W/mK TC. The new material formed can be used in building materials for higheefficiency energy storage.
The thermal performance of the foam graphite can be further improved by using some physical treatment. It was reported that the TC of the compressed expanded natural graphite (CENG)/ paraffin wax PCM composite was boosted by increasing the CENG bulk density. The TC was up to 10.1W/mK along the compression direction when the bulk density was 143 kg/m3, which is 33.66 times larger than that of the pure paraffinwax. The melting time of the composite was 169 s, which was half of that of the 23 kg/m3 bulk density counterpart. It was interesting that the TC perpendicular to the compression direction was 20.2W/mK for the 143 g/ m3 bulk density counterpart, which provided important evaluation data for the future design of TES systems [97]. The annealing in the foam graphite is also an effective method to boost the TC of foam graphite/paraffin wax PCM composites [98]. Under the similar filling volume fraction of paraffin wax (~86%), the TC of the annealed foam could reach 3.61W/mK, which is much larger than that of the uneannealed counterpart (1.65W/mK). The excellent cycling stability was also confirmed in this annealed material.
Owing to the excellent heat transport, the foam graphite/PCMs composites received great attention in the solar TES field. In the high temperature surroundings of CSP plants, the graphite foameMgCl2 combination was applied to the TES system, in which graphite foam was added to considerably enhance the TC of the high melting point of MgCl2 (714 C). According to the exergy analysis for this system (Fig. 18), the round-trip exergy efficiency increased from 68% to 97% with the aid of foam graphite, and the number of HTF pipes was found to decrease by eightefold from 40,000 to 5000, resulting in a significant cost reduction of CSP plants [99].

sections.heading: 4.3. Fins/PCMs composites
sections.text:
The introduction of fins into the PCMsecontaining TES system greatly improves the storage performance and reduces the phase change time. The layout of the fins is one of the key points that cannot be ignored in the performance of TES systems. In previous sections, we reviewed the effects of the fins. Generally, flat horizontally arranged fins are commonly used for the thermal enhancement of TES systems [42,49,55], and the storage efficiency of thermal energy received a large boost. Furthermore, therewas an internal finehoneycomb core construction (Fig.19) that could boost the temperature of the PCMs in the SAH by approximately 2e8.8 C [100]. The charge/discharge time was also significantly shortened by using these fins.
The finned tubes are also popular in the PCMsecontaining TES system, as shown in Refs. [56,57]. The orientation of the fins on the tubes (longitudinal or circular) had different effects on the thermal transport of the TES system according to these reports [56,57,101,102]. The longitudinal fins are easy to design and fabricate in tubes, and the circular fins expand the thermal transport surface between the PCMs and HTF. Gil et al. performed an experimental analysis of the effective TC enhancement of PCMs using circular finned tubes in high temperature bulk tanks [101]. The TC received a 4.1e25.8% improvement for the different flow speeds of HTF cases after the fin installation, which increased the charge speed of the PCMs in the TES tanks for the solar cooling system. Almsater et al. reduced the thermal resistance by utilizing heat pipes with longitudinal fins. This measure not only increased the energy storage compared with bare heat pipes by 106% but also achieved a 79% increase in the energy discharge. This thermal enhancement in PCMs provided huge benefits for thermal power plants [102].
According to the above studies, the foam skeleton or fin skeleton do not encounter the issues of mobility and dispersibility pertaining to the nanoparticles. Instead, their complex connecting structures and wide heat exchange area enable the PCM composites to have high TES. Furthermore, the foam skeleton and fin skeleton can be well-adapted to both heat conduction in the solid state and heat convection in the liquid state. These merits indeed enhance the TES of the energy system and improve the charge/discharge speed of
nergy, 69 (2014), W. Zhao, D.M. France, W. Yu, T. Kim, D. Singh, Phase change material entrated solar power plants, 134e146, Copyright (2019), with permission from Elsevier).
PCMs, which helps the PCMs better demonstrate the ability of solar energy storage.

sections.heading: 5. Evaluation methods for PCMs
sections.text: To obtain high TC of heat storage materials and improve the solar thermal application status, thermal enhancement of PCMs is of significance for TES systems. Evaluation methods to judge the thermal enhancement effect on PCM composites therefore play an indispensable role in the optimization design of PCM composites. In this section, the most representative evaluation methods will be discussed from both experimental measurement and numerical simulation aspects.

sections.heading: 5.1. Experimental measurements
sections.text:
Because of the multiscale feature of most micro/nanoePCMs, unconventional measurement techniques are required to complete the thermophysical property characterizations [5,103]. Typically, the transient hotewire method [104e106], transient plane source method [107e109], laser flash method [110e112] and 3u method [113e116] are the most representative experimental measurement techniques currently utilized. They are able to quickly and accurately measure the TC values, and thus are extremely important in the studies of micro/nanoePCMs. Fig. 20 illustrates the basic test structure for the four measurement techniques.
The transient hotewire method is one type of hotewire method. In brief, a hotewire is buried into the solid, powder or
fluid PCM samples. The heat conduction process is triggered by an instantaneous heating pulse from the hotewire to the sample. By monitoring the temperature response of the hotewire, the thermophysical parameters of the PCM sample can be quickly gained. Some PCMs have been measured by using this method. For example, the MWCNTs/graphene/graphite nanoparticle/stearic acid composite PCMs were measured by using this method [73]. In addition, foammetalereinforced PCMs were also measured via this method [88]. Notice that the transient hotewire method is most commonly used for themeasurement of colloidal suspension PCMs, e.g., palmitic acid/DWCNTs [81], lauric acid/SWCNHs [82] and paraffin wax/CNFs [86]. Although the result of the measurement would not be affected by the heat convection during the measurement, the internal structures of the sample are easily damaged when the hotewire is inserted into them.
The transient plane source method is also commonly used for the TC measurement of PCMs. The thermophysical parameters of the sample are detected through the heat flow from a planeeshape sensor. Specifically, the sensor heats the samples as a planeeshape heat source and detects the heat flow rate, which depends on the thermal transport properties of the samples. An important feature for the test structure is that both sides of the sensor need to in contact with the samples. Uniformity is necessary for the samples, since the heating is assumed to be oneedimensional. The transient plane source method can measure the TC of MPSiO2 [68] or graphite [76] nanoparticleereinforced PCMs, Cu [92] or TiO2 [89] foam skeletonereinforced PCMs, and the colloidal suspension PCMs [87]. However, with this method, it is difficult to accurately
obtain the thermophysical parameters of uneven samples. The laser flashmethod is a nonecontact method, which involves heating the samples through a short energy pulse on one side of the samples. The thermophysical parameters can be determined by measuring the temperature rise on the other side of the samples. This method saves the sample processing steps required for the contact measurement techniques, which usually breaks the integrity of the sample's structure. However, this nonecontact method must meet the following conditions. First, the sample must be uniformly opaque. Second, the energy pulse width needs to be sufficiently small. Third, energy pulse should be completely absorbed by the side of the sample being illuminated. Fourth, there is no or negligible heat loss on the sample surface. Overall, laser flash method is used to measure bulk PCMs, such as AleC nanoparticles paraffin wax PCMs [63], erythritol/foam graphite PCMs [95] and expanded graphite/paraffin PCM composites [96].
The 3umethod is relatively new technique that originated in the 1990s. The most classic form of the 3umethod uses a metal strip to directly heat the bulk sample. The most prominent feature is that a small sinusoidal current at angular frequency u is fed into themetal strip, and the voltage response of the strip contains the first and third harmonics of the voltage (1u voltage and 3u voltage), which are rich with information about the thermophysical parameters of the sample. The 3u method has the advantages of a minimized radiation effect and facile acquisition of temperature dependence of TC over the steadyestatemethod, though it takesmore time than other transient measurement techniques. This method can measure the thermophysical properties for various categories of samples (bulk, nanopowder, fluid, films, anisotropic samples, and
nanotubes) under a wide temperature range (10e800 K). The method has also been successfully used for the TC measurement of micro/nanoePCMs, such as adipic acid/sebacic acid/GNP eutectic PCMs [117], multielayer film PCMs [118] and myristic acid/graphite nanoplates PCM composites [119]. A recent study by Qiu et al. [120e122] developed a soecalled freestanding sensorebased 3u method, which opens up new horizons for the 3umethod owing to the excellent applicability to a range of dense and porous materials, the nonedestructive measurement and the simultaneous extraction of the thermal contact resistance. Urea formaldehydeeparaffin PCM microcapsules were characterized by the freestanding sensorebased 3u method. This measurement not only provided a reliable basis for the study of the thermal transport mechanisms of PCM microcapsules but also showed improved evaluation tools for the further design, development and controllable preparation of PCMs [123].

sections.heading: 5.2. Numerical simulations
sections.text:
Although there are many experimental methods that can evaluate the thermal transport of PCMs in the phase change process, numerical simulations are also powerful tools in the optimization design of PCMs (Fig. 21). By employing different models (e.g., energy balance method, finite element simulation) or commercial software (e.g., computational fluid dynamics (CFD) software packages, such as FLUENT, ANSYS and COMSOL), the simulation environment can describe the phase change process well. The structural and operational parameters after optimization can provide guidance for the thermal enhancement for PCMs and PCMsecontaining
TES systems. Numerical simulations usually take the following steps: (1) identify and establish the corresponding geometric boundaries, (2) choose the right motion and energy model, (3) import or assume the physical parameters of the relevant components and environmental parameters, and (4) determine the optimal value of thermal enhancement by specific numerical simulation. As the most common analytical methods for solving engineering problems, the energy balance method [54,102,124,125] and the enthalpy method [11,54,91,97] are widely used to simulate the thermal transport behaviour of PCMs during the solidification and melting processes. To simulate the thermal transport of PCMs in complex TES systems more efficiently, the finite element method [93,126,127] and CFD modelling method [40,55,91,128e131] are introduced, which can easily accomplish the simulation.
The energy balance method is usually used to study the flow of energy based on energy conservation and to analyse the thermal enhancement effect in PCMs. The energy equation for a system without energy generation is as follows:
EIn EOut ¼ ESt (9)
where E denotes energy value. The subscripts In, Out and St denote the input value, the output value and the stay value in the system, respectively. For solar energy devices with PCMs, EIn is usually the solar energy received by the devices and EOut is the energy loss from the devices. Generally, ESt includes the energy transfer between different parts of the devices and the energy retention of different parts. When ESt of the PCMs needs to be considered, the energy equation between PCMs and other parts must be used. With the help of this method, Arias et al. studied the segregation of particles in the solidification of PCMs and its dependence on shape and dimension factors [124]. Hossain et al. studied the effect of the nanoparticle volume fraction and porous medium porosity on the thermal transport and melt speed of PCMs [125]. Based on the flow and change of energy, the thermal enhancement effect can be reliably judged and guided, which further improves the TES capability of PCMs.
The enthalpy method is based on the enthalpy changes of various parts of the system. The major advantages of this method include the ability to avoid direct front tracking when dealing with materials that melt or solidify over a range of temperatures, which
enable complex geometries to be simulated via this method. The enthalpy equation for solidification/melting is as follows:
vðrHÞ vt þ V,ðrnHÞ ¼ V,ðkVTÞ þ S (10) where H¼ hþDH, h ¼ hRef þ R T TRef cpdT , S is source term depending on the sample condition, H is the total enthalpy, which includes the sensible heat enthalpy h and the latent heat enthalpy DH, n is fluid velocity, and cp is the constant pressure specific heat capacity. The subscript Ref denotes the reference value. The initial condition T(x,y,z,t0)¼ Tinit needs to be considered in the simulation, and the boundary conditions, such as ek∙vT/vn¼ q0 or ek∙vT/ vn¼ hSur(TeTo), also should be considered, where q0 is the heat flux, hSur is the air surface heat transfer coefficient, and To is the ambient temperature. It is clearly seen in Eq. (10) that the characteristics of the enthalpy method include the following: (1) the governing equation is similar to the singleephase equation, which provides an easier solution to phase change problems; (2) there are no explicit conditions to be satisfied at the solideliquid interface, and the enthalpy method thus relates to the solution within a mushy zone, involving both the solid phase and the liquid phase [91]. Hence, it is understandable that a large number of studies on PCM problems are based on the enthalpy method. For example, Han et al. studied the thermal energy storage and release processes in the multiecavityestructured PCM microcapsules and found the charge/ discharge speed of PCMs will be accelerated by increasing the number of cavities and cavity interlayers in the microcapsules [11]. The feature is that the enthalpymethod possesses a pivotal position in the engineering TES system [54], providing a reliable evaluation for engineering applications of PCMs.
The finite element simulation method subdivides a large phase change energy storage system into smaller and simpler elements and simulates them separately, which is called the discretization strategy. The simulation usually takes the following steps: (1) the creation of finite element meshes, (2) the selection of a basis function of reference elements and (3) the mapping of reference elements onto the element meshes. There are many types of discretization strategies, such as the basic versions, i.e., the heversion and peversion. Both of these versions are numerical methods for solving partial differential equations. Their biggest difference is that
the polynomial degrees of the elements are fixed and the mesh is refined in the heversion, while the finite element mesh is fixed, and the polynomial degrees of elements are increased in the peversion [132,133]. After the simulation, the subdivided elements are then assembled into a larger system, which makes it easier to model the thermal transport problem during the phase change process. The finite element simulation method provides a wide range of simulation options for controlling the complexity of both the modelling and the analysis in a system and has the ability to manage the required level of accuracy and computational time simultaneously, which can address most engineering application issues. As one of the research hotspots in the engineering field, i.e., the behaviour of PCMs, can be accurately and reliably described by the finite element simulation method [134]. For instance, the influence of the porosity and the TC of foam metal on the PCMs' TC andmelting process was studied byWang et al. [126]. The optimum fin structure was obtained, which greatly enhanced the solidification velocity of PCMs, in a marked contrast to the speed increase via the dispersed Cu nanoparticles by Lohrasbi et al. [127]. The finite element simulation method provides the accurate prediction of the thermal enhancement effect for the micro/nanoePCMs.
For reaching a higheefficiency finite element simulation, the CFDmodellingmethod was developed as a powerful tool to analyse engineering studies with the largest and the most complex problems, such as the solidification/melting process in PCMs for solar thermal applications. This method also involves fluid mechanics, such as turbulencemodels and twoephase flow, which focus on the flow of gas and liquid. CFD can deal with the complex problems of fluid flows in solar thermal applications, such as HTF with different flow rates. There are different CFD software packages that have been used in PCMs studies, including FLUENT, ANSYS and COMSOL. Take FLUENT software as an example, the physical engineering problem is drawn and meshed in a specific geometric model using mesh generation tools, such as Gambit. Then, the boundary layers and zone types are defined, and themesh is exported to the FLUENT software for the simulation with suitable grid sizes and time steps [135]. Therefore, to analyse the thermal enhancement during the solidification process of PCMs or the heat exchange process of colloidal suspensions, CFD is undoubtedly an ideal numerical simulation method, which can be seen in several studies using this method; Mahdi et al. combined nanoparticles successively with metal foam or metal fins in a triplexetube PCMsecontaining TES system, and confirmed the thermal enhancement due to this combination and internal elements for the improvement of the TES system [130,131]. Future work on PCMsecontaining TES analysis will see the development of the CFD modelling method with highereefficiency computing power.
To grasp the internal or external thermal energy exchange of PCMs or PCMsecontaining TES systems, there is no doubt that the combination of the experimental data and the simulation mechanism is an imperative trend. For the TC and LH boost of the PCMs or the thermal energy utilization of the TES system, this combination provides accurate data and reliable evidence for the optimized design of PCMecontaining TES systems.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusions
sections.text:
This review article shows the main categories of micro/ nanoePCMs and their role in solar thermal energy recycling systems. Some typical thermal enhancement approaches for PCMs, such as composite reinforcement using nanoparticles or skeletons, are also discussed. The main conclusions from recent progress are summarized as follows:
1. Organic PCMs are more suitable for solar energy recovery systems due to their benefits, such as high stability, good recyclability and no need for supercooling. 2. The usage of PCMs boosts the daily energy storage and the utilization of a solar TES system by extending the operating time. However, their enhancement effect on the system's energy absorption is not obvious when the amount of solar energy reaches the peak of the day. 3. The dispersion effect of nanoparticles is the basic starting point of TC enhancement of the PCMs. The excellent TC enhancement effect and good stability in PCMs make the carbonebased nanoparticles able to replace the conventional metal nanoparticles. For PCM colloidal suspensions, the mobility and high TC of the nanoparticles ensure that energy is stored and released well during the flow. 4. Skeleton materials typified by foams and fins also exhibit remarkably high thermal enhancement effects. The thermal transport network constructed by the foam materials makes their TC enhancement effect better than the nanoparticles, while the fins enhance the heat exchange rate between the PCMs and the solar collection system, which improves the overall energy utilization.
In summary, micro/nanoePCMs with enhanced thermal transport performances are the key to increasing the efficiency of solar TES materials and the related systems. The optimization design of PCMsecontaining TES systems will enable enhanced solar energy efficiency. It is envisioned that the progress of micro/nanoePCMs is still the main area of focus for solar thermal applications in the future.

sections.heading: 7. Future recommendations
sections.text:
Based on this review, PCMs play an important role as potential energy storage components for solar TES systems. The representative thermal enhancement methods for PCMs and TES systems are also introduced in detail. The following are some recommendations to further studies on the improvement of the PCMsecontaining TES capability:
1. At present, many PCMs in solar energy storage devices are single type materials (mostly paraffin wax). The mixture of multiple PCMs have incomparable advantages, such as high TES density and high stability. Future work can focus on designing and developing novel PCM mixtures to accomplish the mission of the ever-increasing solar energy storage capacity. 2. Eliminating the effect of supercooling will further boost the thermal enhancement of PCMs. Good dispersion of nanoparticles in the PCMs will constantly contribute to the thermal stability in the phase change cycles. 3. The mutual combination of multiple thermal enhancements, such as nanoparticles, foams, and fins, helps the PCMs to achieve greater promotion in thermal transport than a single thermal enhancement method.
It can be foreseen that the optimized PCMsecontaining TES systems will become an indispensable part in the technical field of renewable energy utilization. By using LH to store energy, the solar energy utilization rate will improve considerably and will occupy a vital position in the future solar energy industry.

metadata.abstractText: Solar energy, which is welleknown for its inexhaustible and environmentally friendly properties, is among the most promising sources of energy. Solar energy is usually collected by a heat mediumeheat transfer fluid (HTF) in the form of heat and is then transported to production and human use. Due to the challenges of variant weather, climate and seasons, solar heating or power supply devices based on thermal energy storage (TES) components that can operate continuously and without interruption are needed. Phase change materials (PCMs) as latent heat storage material have considerably smaller weights and volumes to store larger amount of energy, which can help the solar thermal equipment capture more solar energy. Nevertheless, conventional PCMs with low thermal conductivity (TC) lead to long energy storage/release times for TES components, which significantly reduces the TES efficiency. To improve the overall TES performance, the key is to accelerate the heat storage/release process via boosting the TC of the PCMs. Based on cuttingeedge theoretical and experimental studies, we review the typical thermal enhancement advances in micro/nanoePCMs in this field. © 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
